page.title: 03Small Farm Work, N. Lopham
page.content:
On the Callows' small farm (see page 2) they grow mostly arable crops, such as wheat, barley, sugar beet and potatoes. To make a good income, they also breed and rear animals. They fatten and sell geese at Christmas time. They breed pigs, which are sold at 14 weeks for fattening elsewhere. At the moment, they own 11 breeding pigs and a boar. They rear cattle. Some are Hereford/Friesian cross and some are Limousin. The Callows don't breed the calves, but buy them in at 2 weeks, when they cost about Â£100 each.
In order to make full use of their machinery and to add to their income, the Callows rent meadows and sell the hay. They also buy, cart and sell straw.
